thread.title: Sens coach Dave Cameron not about to panic about lack of production | Garrioch |
thread.title_full: Sens coach Dave Cameron not about to panic about lack of production | Garrioch |

author: torontosun.com
title: Sens coach Dave Cameron not about to panic about lack of production | Garrioch |
text:
On election day, Dave Cameron elected not to change his lines.
He wants to give this group of Senators some time to get their act together.
Yes, the Senators' coach would like to see more production up front from more than the trio of Kyle Turris, Mark Stone and Mike Hoffman but as the Senators took the ice at the Canadian International Hockey Academy in Rockland Monday, Cameron opted not to make any changes.
Instead, the status quo remained.
And while practice might be the time to experiment with three days before the Senators face the New Jersey Devils Thursday night at the Canadian Tire Centre, Cameron indicated he was pleased with the club's effort in a 4-3 shootout loss to the Nashville Predators Saturday night and the lines won't be shifted.
Right now, Cameron believes it's in the best interests of the team to leave everything alone and, hopefully, the production will follow.
"Scoring comes in spits and spurts and we're not ready to panic yet," said Cameron after the one-hour skate. "If we think it's in the best interest of the team to move guys around we will and we'll just go from there."
Right now, Cameron doesn't want to make any moves.
As noted, the Senators have scored 19 goals this season and nine of those have come from Turris' trio which is wonderful for them because they've been able to help the club have success but it also means there are others who have to come through if Ottawa is going to make the playoffs.
An area of concern through the first six games is the play of winger Bobby Ryan and centre Mika Zibanejad. With winger Clarke MacArthur out for what's believed to be an extended period with a possible concussion, Cameron has moved veteran winger Milan Michalek to the left side to see if he can spark the duo.
One change that could be made at some point is moving winger Shane Prince up the depth chart. He was sixth in the AHL in goal-scoring last season and has been used in a fourth-line role since he got into the lineup. He had some success in the pre-season so that's a possibility if things don't change.
For now, the key is to get Ryan and Zibanejad going.
Ryan, the club's highest-paid player at $7.25 million this season, has only one goal and that came into an empty net against the Blue Jackets last Wednesday in Columbus while Zibanejad, 22, who has been a notoriously slow starter, scored his only goal of the season in the same game.
Ryan believes it's early and it's going to take time to build chemistry.
"We've seen through six games, we've had three different linemates, right? You don't have a whole lot of time to develop things," said Ryan. "Even through training camp, Mika and I only skated together in one game. It wasn't consistent, it was a bit messy. So now we're having a week here where we can get some reps, get some flow, some 2-on-1's, 3-on-2's, and build from there.
"It's just reps (and) repetition. We know each other fairly well, you take (Hoffman) away, throw in a guy like (Michalek), they're very different. You have to find a way to create down low because that's the way (Michalek) and I like to play, and I think that's where our line is going to be good."
Getting secondary scoring would take offensive pressure off Turris, Hoffman and Stone to carry the load. They didn't score in a 2-0 loss in Pittsburgh last week and the result was a shutout for the first time in 178 games. They can't be expected to be on the board every night.
Cameron said he liked the way Jean-Gabriel Pageau contributed with Alex Chiasson and Curtis Lazar Saturday. They didn't score but had chances but Cameron felt it was the club's best all-around effort of the season.
"I thought all four lines were real good. I thought our game was real good. The only thing that wasn't real good was the result," Cameron said. "It's a four-line league. I think all the teams who have had success are able to play four lines so is it important for us to be able to rely on four lines? Absolutely."
One thing Cameron doesn't want to see is guys pressing to score.
"It's simple. You play to your level," he said. "And you focus on how you play. Sometimes you score and sometimes you don't. Don't start chasing the game by cheating."
The sooner the scoring happens for other lines the better it will be for the Senators to have consistency in the win column.
Otherwise, people will cast their ballots for Cameron to make changes to get the offence going.
Twitter: @ sungarrioch
